title.narrative: MIGRATORY BIRD CONSERVATION IN WESTERN PORTLAND BIGHT, JAMAICA

description.narrative: The Portland Bight Protected Area (PBPA) is the largest protected area in Jamaica, and makes up about 10% of the country. Over 100 neotropical migrant species are known to occur in the PBPA, including reddish egret, red knot, white-crowned pigeon, Bicknells thrush, Swainsons warbler, prairie warbler and worm-eating warbler. The principal threat faced by these species is habitat destruction and disturbance, and to a lesser extent illegal hunting. This project will increase support for bird conservation through educational programs at a new conservation center in the PBPA, as well as surrounding communities. The project will also focus on community monitoring and enforcement, and support for development of sustainable ecotourism at the conservation center...

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: MIGRATORY BIRD CONSERVATION IN WESTERN PORTLAND BIGHT, JAMAICA

description.narrative: This project will: 1) actively and collaboratively manage the Western Portland Bight Reserve (WPBR) to support migratory bird conservation; 2) improve Caribbean Coastal Area Management Foundations capacity to implement conservation actions in WPBR; 3) survey baseline conditions for NMB populations and habitat and complete a baseline report; 4) develop and implement NMB bird population and habitat monitoring; 5) develop and implement community enforcement, monitoring and conservation actions; 6) promote bird-related tourism as a source of support and sustainable livelihoods; 7) operationalize the visitor center to support education, enforcement, and community-based ecotourism; and 8) increase awareness and support for WPBR management by providing educational programs for resident adults and children.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: Sustainable Management and Preservation of the Jamaican Iguana, Cyclura collei

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to ensure that the in situ protection program for the Jamaican.iguana can continue and improve its performance while simultaneously improving the capacity of.the government of Jamaica to execute and manage the program. The project will also initiate a.process to stop the illegal charcoal production taking place within the range of the iguana in..the Hellshire Hills of the Portland Bight Protected Area, and help prepare for an emergency.translocation of the entire population of iguanas in the event of massive development pressures..The project will also seek to raise public awareness of the species and the treats it currently faces so that citizenry can advocate on behalf of the species.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Sustainable Management and Preservaton of the Jamaican Iguana, Cyclura collei

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to ensure that the in situ protection program for the Jamaican iguana can continue and improve its performance, while simultaneously improving the capacity of the government of Jamaica to execute and manage the program. The project will also initiate a process to stop the illegal charcoal production taking place within the range of the iguana in the Hellshire Hills of the Portland Bight Protected Area, and help prepare for an emergency translocation of the entire population of iguanas in the event of massive development pressures. The project will also seek to raise public awarene4ss of the species and the threats it currently faces so that citizenry can advocate on behalf of the species.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

description.narrative: The Blue and John Crow Mountains National Park (BJCMNP) covers 101,802 acres and contains the largest continuous block of natural, closed broadleaf forest remaining in Jamaica. The location is extremely important for 45 migratory bird species as stopover and wintering habitat. Unfortunately, Jamaica Conservation and Development Trust (JCDT), the official park administrator, receives only 30% of its operating budget from the government. The BJCMNP is threatened by lack of funding; encroachment from neighboring communities; unmarked boundaries and limited economic opportunity leading to the spread of agricultural plots in certain areas of the park. Partners will combat these threats by 1) building the capacity of JCDT and support the creation of new revenue streams to finance the management and law enforcement needs of the BJCMNP; 2) restoring 50 acres of habitat for migratory birds through the planting of 7,500 native trees, 3) hiring and training two new Park Rangers; 4) improving park boundary markers; 5) conducting a two-day Agroforestry Workshop with 20 individuals from five communities (on the topics of reforestation and sustainable agricultural practices and 6) re-establishing a bird monitoring program in the BJCMNP and survey specifically for the Bicknell's Thrush.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance

title.narrative: Management and Preservation of the Jamaican Iguana

description.narrative: This project supports the conservation of the critically endangered Jamaican Iguana (Cyclura collei), in the Hellshire Hills of Jamaica by establishing a comprehensive management strategy. The Hellshire Hills are one of the last significant expanses of tropical dry forest in the Caribbean and make up part of the Portland Bight Protected Area, home to a variety of other threatened species. The project is intended to ensure the survival of the Jamaican Iguana and its ecosystem by building on the species current conservation program. This species exists only within a small core area of the Hellshire Hills and is threatened by invasive mammals. Proposed project activities include: 1) An in-depth exploration and evaluation of the area outside of the core zone, resulting in the designation of a buffer zone surrounding the core area; 2) An expansion and revitalization of the species headstart program, resulting in greater and more rapid output and an increased wild population growth rate; and 3) a revised iguana monitoring program allowing for a rigorous assessment of the population during the implementation of improvements and on-going into the future.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Agency for International Development, Development Assistance

title.narrative: Leveraging enhanced SMART marine capacity and implementation globally to strengthen, monitor, and evaluate marine protected area management effectiveness in Jamaica

description.narrative: This project supports conservation efforts in Jamaica by building advanced capacity in marine protected area management and enforcement, in addition to creating a global foundation for advanced training in the Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool (SMART) for expanded implementation in the marine environment. More than 250,000 Jamaicans rely on fishing as their sole income generating activity, however under the current levels of exploitation, fisheries are unsustainable. This project will contribute to the conservation of critical mangrove, seagrass, and coral reef ecosystems, as well as important spawning and nursery grounds by addressing the impacts of unsustainable fishing practices, poaching, and overfishing. Specific activities include: 1) Development of a comprehensive, standardized SMART Marine training module to enhance the capacity of marine conservation practitioners globally; 2) Building advanced capacity of government, non-governmental agencies, and community organizations in Jamaica to implement a SMART-based adaptive management approach to the operation, monitoring, and evaluation of marine protected areas; and 3) Supporting the implementation of SMART at the East Portland Fish Sanctuary as a demonstration site for Jamaica, with subsequent, hands-on application for other selected protected areas in Jamaica.

Agency for International Development, Development Assistance

description.narrative: The Blue and John Crow Mountains National Park is an area of exceptional importance for migratory birds and has been globally recognized as a United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) World Heritage Site, an Important Bird Area, a Key Biodiversity Area, an Alliance for Zero Extinction site, and a Center of Plant Diversity. It is managed by the non-profit organization Jamaica Conservation and Development Trust (JCDT) in partnership with the government. While the park serves as essential wintering grounds for many Neotropical migratory birds, this project focuses on improving habitat for Prairie Warbler, a species for which tropical deforestation is the primary threat. Partners will build upon the accomplishments of Phase I - including successful reforestation, community engagement, expanded revenue generation by JCDT and the initiation of a bird monitoring program - by scaling up reforestation, addressing the causes of park encroachment and deforestation, expanding educational outreach, and refining bird monitoring. American Bird Conservancy and JCDT will work in collaboration with local communities to 1) plant 12,000 native trees to restore over 40 to 50 acres of tropical forest; 2) mark 7 miles of park boundaries using native Blue Mahoe trees; 3) implement an innovative mentorship program to address the root causes of encroachment and subsequent deforestation; 4) provide targeted environmental outreach to local communities; and 5) expand a bird monitoring program to better survey Neotropical migratory birds and to understand their use of restored habitats and recently burned areas.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date
